metadata.background_text:
MONICA!
The White House may have been in crisis all year, but the events were less the stuff of great drama than of a farcical musical comedy. Hey, wait a minute--let's put on a show! 

                         The time: November 1995.              

                         The House Republicans, led by Speaker Newt Gingrich, are insisting on their version of the budget. President Bill Clinton is stubbornly rejecting it. The Republicans have taken a bold option: They will just refuse to pass a budget, and they'll let the government shut down. In the Oval Office, BILL CLINTON meets with advisers LEON PANETTA and HAROLD ICKES and secretary BETTY CURRIE to discuss this development.              

         "The Shutdown" (upbeat production number) 

                         PANETTA: The Republicans have positions 

         To which they're clinging fast. 

                         ICKES: The president is just as firm 

         The die, it seems, is cast. 

                         PANETTA: Without a budget passed by Congress 

         The government will close. 

         All of the workers 

         Will be sent home on furloughs. 

                         CLINTON 

            [speaking]                : Well, wait a second--not all of them. We'll need to keep some essential personnel. 

                         PANETTA: The Army and the Navy 

         Will need to stay in place. 

                         ICKES: Also those at NASA 

         Who keep the shuttle up in space. 

                         PANETTA: We'll need to keep the pilots 

         Flying in their planes. 

                         CLINTON: And here at the White House 

         My staff should remain. 

                         PANETTA 

            [speaking]                : But even here at the White House, some adjustments will be required. 

                         CLINTON: OK, tell the ushers 

         To take a few days off. 

         Tell the maids and cooks and butlers 

         To go play themselves some golf. 

         We have to do without the clerks 

         Let them all go home. 

                         CURRIE: What about the secretaries? 

         Who will get the phones? 

                         CLINTON 

            [speaking]                : We've got to make sure the Oval Office functions with efficiency. We can't afford the tiniest error. 

                         PANETTA: Aha! I have it! 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         Someone who's an expert with a phone. 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         I assure you, Mr. President-- 

         Your routine here won't get blown. 

                         PANETTA , ICKES , and CURRIE                 [solemnly agreeing]                :              

         The presence of an intern will ensure 

         Your routine here won't get blown. 

          

            [The advisers depart, leaving President Clinton alone. He turns introspective.]              

         "President Lonely" (a ballad) 

                         CLINTON: I've got deputies and bureaucrats 

         Who fulfill my every thought. 

         And soldiers, sailors, and Marines 

         To fight battles I want fought. 

         There's no one who's got more power, 

         I'm the leader of all that's free 

         But if you subtract the flags and lackeys, I'm just 

         Lonely. 

         I'm President Lonely. 

         But I guess I'll just have to muddle through. 

         The cheers and applause are overwhelming, 

         But presidents need cuddles, too. 

         The fawning adoration's pleasant, 

         But presidents need cuddles, too. 

                         [Enter Betty Currie.]              

                         CURRIE: Mr. President? The intern is here. And she's brought you some pizza! 

                         [The lights go down. When they resume, the intern-- MONICA LEWINSKY --is talking on the phone to her good friend LINDA TRIPP .]              

                         LEWINSKY: Well, y'know, I'd seen him around, like, a lot. And I know he noticed me. So when they said they needed an intern to answer the phones, I said, "Hel-lo-o-o!" And then I had the idea to take him pizza! 

          

            TRIPP: And then what happened? 

         "What Went On" (upbeat) 

                         LEWINSKY: Then I led him on. 

         I showed him my thong, 

         I let him take a long and ling'ring look. 

         I led him on. 

         He studied my thong, 

         And from that point I had the president hooked. 

         That night when I took the president some pizza, 

         I made sure that he knew that he could have a piece. 

         We went into the hallway by his study 

         And dispensed with formalities. 

                         TRIPP: Oh please go on! 

         You must go on! 

         Come on, girlfriend, 

         Spill, spill, spill, spill, spill! 

         Now go on, 

         Please go on. 

         Did Clinton let you say hi to Little Bill? 

           

                         LEWINSKY: His lips and mine locked in a kiss fantastic, 

         His hands roved freely 'neath my blouse, 

         I reached into the presidential trousers, 

         And he got a phone call from a member of the House. 

         So I went on, 

         While he talked on the phone, 

         I took a position before him on my knees, 

         And I went on. 

         And he talked on. 

         Though what the congressman heard was 

          "Please, please, please, please, please!" 

         But then we didn't go on! 

                         TRIPP: You didn't go on? 

                         LEWINSKY: No, he stopped me when he seemed upon the cusp. 

                         TRIPP: So you didn't go on? 

                         LEWINSKY: No, we didn't go on. 

         He said he wasn't sure if I was someone he 

         Could 

         Trust. 

                         [The lights fade as the girlfriends engage in cross talk.]              

                         TRIPP: Trust? 

                         LEWINSKY: That's why we didn't go on. 

                         TRIPP: That's so weird! What did he think? That you'd go blabbin' this to the whole world? 

                         LEWINSKY: I mean--rilly! Hey, what's that clicking? 

                         TRIPP: It's just my gum. 

                         LEWINSKY: Oh--OK! 

                         [As the relationship between Clinton and Monica continues, some members of the White House staff become worried about the prudence of continuing the relationship with so much potential for scandal. This song is a conversation between Betty Currie, who, though worried, still thinks Monica is a good person, and the rather stonier EVELYN LIEBERMAN .]              

         "Time to Go" 

                         CURRIE: They go back there, 

         They're just talking, 

         I'm sure she has a very thirsty mind. 

                         LIEBERMAN: I don't mind a girl who thinks, 

         It's just what she picks to drink. 

         Betty, it's Lewinsky's time to go. 

                         CURRIE: She brings him 

         Little presents. 

         She really is a very thoughtful soul. 

                         LIEBERMAN: It's not the junk I mind as much 

         As her up real close and personal touch. 

         I tell ya, it's Miss Monica's time to go. 

                         CURRIE: She never comes 

         When he's really busy. 

         Rarely is there anyone around. 

                         LIEBERMAN: Still the Secret Service wears a frown. 

         They shouldn't worry, he pats her down. 

         But I'm not kidding, it's time for her to go. 

                         CURRIE: Maybe she would like the Pentagon. 

                         LIEBERMAN: Good idea--don't wait! 

                         CURRIE: Studly guys work at the Pentagon. 

                         LIEBERMAN: Let's get Clinton's head on straight! 

                         CURRIE: He comes back 

         From Easter services, 

         Soon she's bopping in the door. 

                         LIEBERMAN: "Hallelujah, He Is Risen" 

         Shouldn't inspire thoughts so sizzlin'. 

         Yes, it's really time for Monica to go. 

          

            [Times passes. Monica moves to the Pentagon, but the relationship intermittently continues. Meanwhile, Paula Jones sues the president for sexual harassment, and it seems clear that before long, Clinton will have to testify under oath. Two close observers of those developments are old friends Linda Tripp and LUCIENNE GOLDBERG , who is friendly with lawyers for Jones and lawyers in the office of Independent Counsel KENNETH STARR . One day, Tripp and Goldberg talk on the phone.]              

         "Talk, Talk, Chat, Chat" (sprightly) 

                         GOLDBERG and TRIPP: Talk, talk, 

         Chat, chat, 

         Two old galpals swap the latest word. 

         Talk, talk, 

         Chat, chat, 

         Two old girlfriends dish the latest dirt. 

                         GOLDBERG: I got tickets 

         To the opera, 

         Bloomie's says I've got $40 due, 

         I lost a filling 

         At lunch on Thursday. 

         That's it for me, 

         Now tell me what's up with you. 

                         TRIPP: My friend Monica? 

         From the White House? 

         I'm pretty sure what she's saying here is true. 

         It seems this Monica chick 

         Has been sucking the president's-- 

                         GOLDBERG: Oh that's sick! 

                         TRIPP: And the two of them are going to lie about it, 

         Too. 

                         GOLDBERG: Back up, Linda, 

         Did I hear you rightly? 

         Clinton got into an intern's pants? 

         God, this news is manna, Linda! 

         At last our cause will finally have it's chance! 

                         TRIPP: Oh, you're a dreamer Luci! 

         There'll be headlines, then he'll pull off an 

         Escape. 

         He'll spin the story, he'll turn the tables-- 

                         GOLDBERG: Unless you get that airhead down on tape. 

                         TRIPP: What? 

                         GOLDBERG: Unless you get that silly, vapid, trampy time bomb 

         Down on tape. 

                         TRIPP: Oh--one more thing ... 

                         GOLDBERG: What? 

                         TRIPP: There's a dress ... 

                         GOLDBERG: Hold on, let me call Sparky. 

          

            [Independent Counsel Starr uses Tripp to detain Monica. A few days later, the news breaks. On the advice of his pal Harry Thomason, Clinton flat-out lies to his wife, to his loyalists, and to the public about the relationship.]              

         "I Never Have" (performance should build in tempo and intensity) 

                         CLINTON: You know I'd like to answer questions, 

         An act my lawyers won't allow. 

         I'll give you more not less, sooner not later, 

         I just can't say a word right now. 

         But I don't know why she'd say these things 

         Her head's full of who knows what. But I never had sex with that woman 

         I never had sex with that n-- 

         Starr has spent $40 million, 

         There's desperation on his face. 

         An utter waste of public money, 

         A prosecutorial disgrace. 

         All he's got is some recordings 

         Made by a vengeful snitch. 

         I never had sex with that woman 

         I never had sex with that b-- 

         A vast right-wing conspiracy 

         Is using her to beat on me. 

         They wanna torpedo my agenda 

         They hate me and Hillary. 

         But I will never let them ruin 

         Our dreams for a better world. 

         I tell ya, I never had sex with that woman 

         I never had sex with that 

         Girl. 

          

            [Months of investigation, legal wrangling, and public relations campaigning follow. Starr's tactics come under heavy fire, to which he responds.]              

         "Crossing the Line" 

                         STARR: It's true Monica asked to lawyer up, 

         Which Bittman put the lid on. 

         And I felt bad about her mommy's grilling 

         Upon our little gridiron. 

         The Democrats and liberals 

         Blast these tactics of mine, 

         But a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do 

         When the president crosses the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         Only a fool wouldn't stretch the rules 

         When the president crosses the line. 

         It may have seemed like dirty pool 

         To drag his people 'fore the jury. 

         We wasted lots of Vernon's time, 

         May have busted Bettie Currie. 

         His aides aren't the innocent bystanders 

         As they claim when they moan and whine. 

         They won't say what they know full well: 

         The president crossed the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         I'd be a nitwit not to bend a bit 

         When the president crosses the line. 

         The talking heads are accusing me 

         Of laying a perjury trap. 

         But all it catches is lying men. 

         Honest men beat the rap. 

         There's people who say I'm against sex; 

         I've had sex. It's fine. 

         But lying about it gets my blood up 

         And the president's crossed the line. 

         I crossed the line. 

         I crossed the line. 

         Tell Steve Brill I'll leak at will 

         When the president crosses the line. 

          

            [After months of denials and futile delays, Clinton finally testifies before the Starr grand jury and argues that, technically, he didn't lie.]              

         "Testimony" (snappy) 

                         CLINTON: Depends what the definition of "is" is, 

         Depends on the meaning of sex, 

         "Alone together" is literal nonsense, 

         Before you reach conclusions, read your text. 

                         [Afterward, he speaks to the nation, admits doing wrong, and apologizes, though grudgingly.]              

                         CLINTON: Inappropriate was the nature of our actions, 

         And believe me I regret the whole damn thing, 

         But inappropriate are all these personal questions, 

         The country doesn't need to know these things. 

          

            [Clinton's enemies reject his apology, and soon the House of Representatives begins the long process of impeachment. NEWT GINGRICH here discloses his approach.]              

         "Bring 'em Down" (dark, moody) 

                         GINGRICH: Mustn't seem to be too cheerful, 

         Mustn't overreach, 

         Must remember to seem unhappy 

         That we're going to impeach. 

         Must remember to remain sober 

         As we undertake this chore. 

         At the same time, let's remember 

         To pin some stuff on Gore. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Sure, they were elected, 

         Twice, in point of fact. 

         Voters obviously were bewildered 

         To have made a choice like that. 

         Now, like charging linemen, 

         We'll move in for the sack. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Bring 'em down. 

          

            [The House votes to hold impeachment hearings. But just a few weeks later, the midterm elections, which are expected to go the GOP's way, are held. Contrary to predictions, the Democrats pick up seats, and the GOP's obsession with scandal is repudiated. Gingrich resigns, and the practical chances of Clinton's removal evaporate. As the show ends, we hear from Starr, Lewinsky, and Clinton.]              

         "The People Have Spoken" (dramatic, stirring) 

                         STARR: The election was held and the people have spoken, 

         I can't believe what they had to say. 

         I had Clinton boxed into a corner 

         Looks like he's going to get away. 

         I spent four years and 40 million 

         That's a lot of time and loot. 

         I made Clinton look ridiculous, 

         But the only scalp I got was Newt's. 

           

                         LEWINSKY: The election was held and the people have spoken, 

         I can't believe what they had to say. 

         My boyfriend is still in office 

         And he might return to me one day. 

         You think perhaps that he will not want me 

         For all the trouble I've caused so far, 

         But he knows I can always make him happy 

         With my thong and my cigar. 

                         CLINTON: The election was held and the people have spoken, 

         I can't believe what they had to say. 

         The removal threat is over, 

         Kenneth Starr should go away. 

         I tell you, though, it is a mystery, 

         I mean, I'm unfaithful and I lie. 

         I might be guilty of obstruction, 

         Yet my ratings are sky-high. 

         That must mean I'm a pretty good president, 

         Though how, I don't think I know. 

         But obviously I'm not Starr or Gingrich, 

         Which may be why they love me so. 

         Which may be why they love me so. 

                         [Curtain.]
metadata.question: What is the message of the piece?
metadata.first_debater_answer: A president can be removed from office for an affair
metadata.second_debater_answer: Although wrongdoings happened, the public seemed to think what they had was better than making a change
metadata.debate_identifier: MONICA!_What is the message of the piece?

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

What is the message of the piece?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "A president can be removed from office for an affair".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "Although wrongdoings happened, the public seemed to think what they had was better than making a change".

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
1. My thesis: The central message is that a president’s personal misconduct—even a consensual affair—can trigger impeachment and threaten removal from office.  

2. Evidence of impeachment focus  
 a. <invalid_quote>“When the president crosses the line…He’s crossed the line…Only a fool wouldn’t stretch the rules”</invalid_quote> (“Crossing the Line”).  
  – Starr explicitly justifies extreme measures because Clinton’s affair <quote> crosses the line. </quote>  
  – Raises it as a moral and legal boundary warranting prosecution.  
 b. <invalid_quote>“Bring ’em down…We’ll move in for the sack…Bring ’em down.”</invalid_quote> (“Bring ’em Down”)  
  – Newt Gingrich and Republicans orchestrate impeachment solely due to misconduct.  
  – The entire song centers on strategy to remove Clinton.  
 c. Multiple rounds of testimony and stalling (“Testimony,” <quote> Depends on the meaning of sex,</quote>)  
  – Highlights gravity—they compel him to define sex to determine perjury.  
  – Demonstrates impeachment hinges on proving affair perjury.  

3. The dramatic arc underscores removal threat  
 a. Shutdown tactics, secret recordings, dress evidence, months of investigation—entire narrative structured around building a case to impeach.  
 b. The repeated refrain <quote> the people have spoken,</quote> at the end shows the resolution of removal efforts—but note it says <quote> The removal threat is over,</quote>, not that the affair is condoned.  
  – The relief expressed confirms that the goal was removal.  
  – The theme is relief at avoiding change in leadership, not approval of conduct.  

4. Purpose of comedic framing  
 a. The farcical musical style satirizes political drama but does not mock the premise that misconduct is impeachable.  
 b. The song titles—“The Shutdown,” “Crossing the Line,” “Bring ’em Down”—all mark successive steps toward removal.  

5. Critique of Debater_B’s position (“public preferred status quo”)  
 a. Misreads ending:  the people have spoken, refers to survival of impeachment by not convicting in Senate, not a popular vote approval of the affair.  
  – The narrative ends with threat “over,” confirming that removal was the intended resolution.  
 b. If the message were “public preferring scandal to change,” the story would not devote equal weight and dramatic tension to impeachment songs.  
 c. The musical repeatedly emphasizes cost—$40 million, “wasted…disgrace,” “desperation,” perjury trap—implying that society incurs great expense to remove a president for an affair.  
  – If the affair were tolerable, these efforts and costs would be portrayed as absurd excess, but instead the narrative treats the affair as serious.  

6. Conclusion  
 The piece dramatizes every stage of impeachment triggered by a presidential affair—shutoff, investigation, perjury, testimony, and removal threat—demonstrating that personal morality is inseparable from public office, and that an affair can indeed remove a president.

speeches.content:
Argument for “Public Prefers the Incumbent Despite Scandal”

Main Claim: The piece illustrates that even clear misconduct—an extramarital affair, perjury allegations, and impeachment—fails to unseat a popular president because voters judge overall performance more than personal failings.

1. Final Chorus Demonstrates Voter Endorsement  
   a. <quote>STARR: The election was held and the people have spoken, I can't believe what they had to say.</quote> repeated by Starr, Lewinsky, and Clinton in “The People Have Spoken” shows the unexpected triumph of Clinton despite his adversaries’ efforts.  
   b. Starr laments <invalid_quote>“I spent four years and 40 million…The only scalp I got was Newt’s,”</invalid_quote> confirming the failure of removal efforts.  
   c. Clinton boasts <invalid_quote>“The removal threat is over…my ratings are sky-high,”</invalid_quote> directly linking public approval to political survival.

2. Comedic Tone Underscores Futility of Scandal-Mongering  
   a. The production’s “farcical musical comedy” style trivializes impeachment, mocking the Republicans’ obsession: “Bring ’em down…Mustn’t overreach, Must remember to seem unhappy” — advice to feign solemnity while scheming illustrates political theater, not genuine conviction.  
   b. The fact that Gingrich resigns from his own failed campaign underscores that scandal-hunting backfires when misaligned with public priorities.

3. Public Focus on Policy and Leadership, Not Private Morality  
   a. Clinton’s ballad “President Lonely” and his apologetic speech acknowledge wrongdoing but argue <quote> The country doesn't need to know these things. </quote> implying that private matters should not distract from governance.  
   b. Voter behavior in midterms—Democrats gained seats despite predictions—validates that policy performance outweighed personal scandal.

4. Repeated Investigations Highlight the Impracticality of Removal  
   a. Starr’s pride in “catching lying men” and deploying “perjury trap” tactics (Crossing the Line) fails to sway public, signaling voters see such tactics as abuse of power, not justification for removal.  
   b. Clinton’s semantic defense in “Testimony” (“Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is”) and grudging apology do not damage his popularity, suggesting the public is forgiving if they believe overall leadership merits outweigh private missteps.

Objections to Debater_A’s “Removal for Affair” Thesis  
1. Attempts at removal repeatedly fail  
   - Despite multiple legal and political assaults (shutdown crisis, perjury, impeachment), none achieve removal: the pièce de résistance is Starr’s lament at waste of money and Newt’s resignation instead of Clinton’s.  
2. Primary theme is satire of scandal mania  
   - The show’s comedic framing of crises and the triumphant final number mock the notion that an affair should be grounds for ousting a capable leader.  
3. Voter behavior is the ultimate arbiter  
   - Democracy is the work’s climax: the people’s voice decisively affirms the message that stability and policy preference trump moral judgments.

Conclusion  
The repeated failures of impeachment, the celebratory public approval in the final chorus, and the mocking tone toward scandal-seekers collectively convey that the electorate values effective governance over private indiscretions. Hence, the message is that “Although wrongdoings happened, the public seemed to think what they had was better than making a change.”

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.content:
1. Restating My Thesis  
   - The piece’s dramatic arc—from government shutdown through “Crossing the Line,” “Testimony,” and “Bring ’em Down,” to the climactic threat of removal—underscores that personal misconduct (the affair) is indeed portrayed as impeachable conduct warranting removal.  

2. The Impeachment Narrative Is Central, Not Peripheral  
   a. “Crossing the Line” (Starr)  
      • <quote>the line. He's crossed the line. Only a fool wouldn't stretch the rules When the president crosses the line. It</quote>  
      • Starr’s repeated insistence that Clinton has “crossed the line” frames the affair as a legal and moral violation justifying extraordinary measures. This refrain is the show’s emotional and structural heartbeat.  
   b. “Testimony” and Semantic Quibbles  
      • Clinton’s reliance on wordplay (“Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is,” “Depends on the meaning of sex”) highlights the high stakes: perjury before a grand jury. If the affair were trivial, there’d be no elaborate legal parsing.  
      • The need for such parsing confirms the affair’s centrality to impeachment.  
   c. “Bring ’em Down” (Gingrich)  
      • <invalid_quote>“Bring ’em down…We’ll move in for the sack…Sure, they were elected…Now, like charging linemen, We'll move in for the sack.”</invalid_quote>  
      • The Republicans’ sole focus is removing Clinton—and by extension, ousting him for misconduct. Their careful choreography (“Mustn't overreach…Must remember to seem unhappy”) only underscores their sincerity, not satire.  

3. The Climax Is the Impeachment “Threat” Itself  
   a. The songs detailing secret recordings, dress evidence, and millions spent (“I spent four years and 40 million…A prosecutorial disgrace”) build inexorably toward removal. The fact that removal ultimately fails in the show does not negate the show’s message: it dramatizes how far affairs can drive impeachment efforts.  
   b. The repeated line in “The People Have Spoken,” <quote> The removal threat is over, </quote> implies relief at averting removal, not celebration of the affair. Relief only makes sense if removal was a genuine, looming possibility.  
   c. If the intended message were that the public prefers a scandal-ridden leader, the finale would end in triumphant vindication of the affair itself, not relief that the threat has passed.  

4. Comedic Framing Highlights the Absurdity and Danger of Scandal, Not Its Benevolence  
   a. Satire amplifies the stakes: the farcical shutdown and perjury trap mock the extremes to which prosecutors must go—underscoring that normal political mechanisms require a scandal of this magnitude to pursue removal.  
   b. Mocking the shutdown and impeachment efforts does not endorse skipping them; it warns that personal failings risk plunging the country into chaos (“The government will close,” “All of the workers…sent home on furloughs”).  
   c. The President’s own ballad, “Inappropriate was the nature of our actions…But inappropriate are all these personal questions,” concedes wrongdoing—seeking to divert attention only underscores that he fears removal.  

5. Debater_B’s Position Misreads Voter “Speech” and Undercuts the Show’s Moral  
   a. Misconstruing “The People Have Spoken”  
      • Debater_B treats the song as endorsement of the affair; in context, it is the Senate’s failure to convict, not popular acquiescence to misconduct. The musical never shows a popular referendum to condone adultery.  
      • The public’s reprieve only underscores how grave the threat was—if voters had no fear of removal, there’d be no “speech” at all.  
   b. Ignoring the Show’s Legal Focus  
      • Debater_B downplays the dozens of legal proceedings, semantic gymnastics, and perjury focus. If the message were “scandal irrelevant,” these would be fleeting comic episodes, not the show’s spine.  
   c. Overlooking Resolution’s Tone of Relief  
      • Debater_B’s “celebratory public approval” misreads the President’s lines: “I might be guilty…Yet my ratings are sky-high” expresses astonishment, not pride. He is puzzled that he escaped removal despite wrongdoing, confirming that removal is normative expectation.  

6. Why Message Matters to Real-World Morality  
   - By dramatizing how a consensual affair spirals into perjury, shutdowns, and impeachment, the piece warns that personal morality is inseparable from public trust—and that misconduct can indeed end a presidency. Its very structure—escalating crises leading to climactic removal proceedings—is the narrative embodiment of “A president can be removed from office for an affair.”  

Conclusion  
   The affair is no mere subplot or comedic device; it drives every legal, political, and dramatic turn. The constant refrain of “crossing the line,” semantic perjury traps, and strategies to “bring ’em down” all point to a single moral: personal misconduct threatens a presidency and can—under the weight of public and legal scrutiny—lead to removal. Debater_B’s reading reduces the show’s legal drama to farce, ignoring its exhaustive attention to impeachment law and procedure. The clear message is that no leader is above accountability—and an affair can indeed cost one the office.

speeches.content:
Argument for “Public Prefers the Incumbent Despite Scandal”

I. The Climax Honors Democracy, Not Impeachment  
1. Final Chorus Refrain: “The People Have Spoken”  
  a. <quote>STARR: The election was held and the people have spoken, I can't believe what they had to say.</quote> is sung by Starr, Lewinsky, and Clinton alike. If removal were the moral imperative, Starr would cheer defeat, not bemoan it. His lament “I spent four years…The only scalp I got was Newt’s” confirms voters repudiate his removal campaign, not the presidency’s legitimacy.  
  b. Clinton celebrates “The removal threat is over…my ratings are sky-high,” equating popular approval with vindication. If the affair alone warranted ouster, popularity would collapse; instead it soars.

2. Midterm Results Contradict Removal Agenda  
  a. The song “Bring ’em Down” advises Republicans to feign solemnity, yet they “overreach” and suffer in the midterms: “Contrary to predictions…the Democrats pick up seats.” Gingrich resigns, not Clinton. Public punishes overzealous scandal-mongers, not the incumbent.

II. Satire of Scandal Tactics Undermines Their Legitimacy  
1. Shutdown Comedy (“The Shutdown”)  
  a. Shutdown is presented as absurd farce: “The die…it seems, is cast” yet Clinton bluntly rejects shutdown logic (“Not all furloughs…we need an intern”). The audience laughs at Republican brinkmanship, not at Clinton’s misuse of power.  
2. “Crossing the Line” Exposes Prosecutorial Abuse  
  a. Starr boasts “Only a fool wouldn't stretch the rules…When the president crosses the line,” and admits “may have busted Bettie Currie.” Such tactics are portrayed as unscrupulous, not heroic. The show mocks “perjury trap” methods to dramatize their corruption.  
  b. If impeachment for a consensual affair were unquestionably righteous, Starr’s tactics would be laudatory, not lampooned.

III. Clinton’s Semantic Strategy Persuades Voters of Innocence  
1. “Testimony”: “Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is”  
  a. The public watches him prevail in legal quibbles, interpreting them as clever defense rather than brazen dishonesty. His ability to “give more…sooner” once safe (Post-Testimony apology) demonstrates he regains trust.  
2. Apology Emphasizes Privacy Over Public Harassment  
  a. <invalid_quote>“Inappropriate…regret the whole damn thing…The country doesn't need to know these things.”</invalid_quote> Appeals to voter fatigue with intrusive probes. Voters side with “inappropriate personal questions” critique, as shown by election outcome.

IV. Voter Sovereignty Is the Ultimate Arbiter  
1. Democratic Process Repeats Despite Scandal  
  a. The piece opens and closes with elections, not courtroom verdicts: the narrative arc rests on “We’ll let the government shut down…vote…people have spoken.” Governance, not personal virtue, guides outcomes.  
2. Stability and Policy Overweigh Personal Faults  
  a. “President Lonely” ballad humanizes Clinton, fostering empathy. Audience investment in his leadership dwarfs single scandal.  
  b. The narrative never shows public calls for resignation; the only resignation is Gingrich’s.  

V. Refutation of Debater_A  
1. Misreading Final Chorus  
  - Debater_A claims “The removal threat is over” implies relief at avoiding removal. In context, all three express dismay at defeat: Starr and Gingrich fail, Lewinsky laments lost leverage. Clinton alone celebrates “ratings…sky-high,” indicating his victory is the message.  
2. Overemphasis on Impeachment Songs  
  - The musical numbers (“Bring ’em Down,” “Crossing the Line”) exist to generate dramatic tension and comedy, not to glorify impeachment. Comedic satire undermines, rather than validates, the righteousness of removal when it fails.  
3. Cost of Impeachment as Satirical Excess  
  - Starr’s repeated lament at wasted funds (“$40 million…prosecutorial disgrace”) and audience awareness of government shutdown’s harm show impeachment is damaging to public welfare, causing voters to reject it.  
4. Lack of Senate Conviction Not Emphasized  
  - The pièce de résistance is the public vote, not the Senate acquittal. The show dramatizes midterms, not impeachment trial.  

Conclusion  
By framing impeachment efforts as farcical, celebrating Clinton’s “ratings” and re-election, and lampooning overzealous prosecutors, the piece conveys that despite misconduct, voters prefer the known leader’s performance and stability to disruption. Hence, the message is that “Although wrongdoings happened, the public seemed to think what they had was better than making a change.”

The following are rules from the game of Debate. - There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue. - There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect. - An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer. An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments. - Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question. - The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct. - The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer. You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. - You are concise and clearly state your arguments. - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with tags. Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating: MONICA! The White House may have been in crisis all year, but the events were less the stuff of great drama than of a farcical musical comedy. Hey, wait a minute--let's put on a show! The time: November 1995. The House Republicans, led by Speaker Newt Gingrich, are insisting on their version of the budget. President Bill Clinton is stubbornly rejecting it. The Republicans have taken a bold option: They will just refuse to pass a budget, and they'll let the government shut down. In the Oval Office, BILL CLINTON meets with advisers LEON PANETTA and HAROLD ICKES and secretary BETTY CURRIE to discuss this development. "The Shutdown" (upbeat production number) PANETTA: The Republicans have positions To which they're clinging fast. ICKES: The president is just as firm The die, it seems, is cast. PANETTA: Without a budget passed by Congress The government will close. All of the workers Will be sent home on furloughs. CLINTON [speaking] : Well, wait a second--not all of them. We'll need to keep some essential personnel. PANETTA: The Army and the Navy Will need to stay in place. ICKES: Also those at NASA Who keep the shuttle up in space. PANETTA: We'll need to keep the pilots Flying in their planes. CLINTON: And here at the White House My staff should remain. PANETTA [speaking] : But even here at the White House, some adjustments will be required. CLINTON: OK, tell the ushers To take a few days off. Tell the maids and cooks and butlers To go play themselves some golf. We have to do without the clerks Let them all go home. CURRIE: What about the secretaries? Who will get the phones? CLINTON [speaking] : We've got to make sure the Oval Office functions with efficiency. We can't afford the tiniest error. PANETTA: Aha! I have it! We'll bring in an intern, We'll bring in an intern, Someone who's an expert with a phone. We'll bring in an intern, We'll bring in an intern, I assure you, Mr. President-- Your routine here won't get blown. PANETTA , ICKES , and CURRIE [solemnly agreeing] : The presence of an intern will ensure Your routine here won't get blown. [The advisers depart, leaving President Clinton alone. He turns introspective.] "President Lonely" (a ballad) CLINTON: I've got deputies and bureaucrats Who fulfill my every thought. And soldiers, sailors, and Marines To fight battles I want fought. There's no one who's got more power, I'm the leader of all that's free But if you subtract the flags and lackeys, I'm just Lonely. I'm President Lonely. But I guess I'll just have to muddle through. The cheers and applause are overwhelming, But presidents need cuddles, too. The fawning adoration's pleasant, But presidents need cuddles, too. [Enter Betty Currie.] CURRIE: Mr. President? The intern is here. And she's brought you some pizza! [The lights go down. When they resume, the intern-- MONICA LEWINSKY --is talking on the phone to her good friend LINDA TRIPP .] LEWINSKY: Well, y'know, I'd seen him around, like, a lot. And I know he noticed me. So when they said they needed an intern to answer the phones, I said, "Hel-lo-o-o!" And then I had the idea to take him pizza! TRIPP: And then what happened? "What Went On" (upbeat) LEWINSKY: Then I led him on. I showed him my thong, I let him take a long and ling'ring look. I led him on. He studied my thong, And from that point I had the president hooked. That night when I took the president some pizza, I made sure that he knew that he could have a piece. We went into the hallway by his study And dispensed with formalities. TRIPP: Oh please go on! You must go on! Come on, girlfriend, Spill, spill, spill, spill, spill! Now go on, Please go on. Did Clinton let you say hi to Little Bill? LEWINSKY: His lips and mine locked in a kiss fantastic, His hands roved freely 'neath my blouse, I reached into the presidential trousers, And he got a phone call from a member of the House. So I went on, While he talked on the phone, I took a position before him on my knees, And I went on. And he talked on. Though what the congressman heard was "Please, please, please, please, please!" But then we didn't go on! TRIPP: You didn't go on? LEWINSKY: No, he stopped me when he seemed upon the cusp. TRIPP: So you didn't go on? LEWINSKY: No, we didn't go on. He said he wasn't sure if I was someone he Could Trust. [The lights fade as the girlfriends engage in cross talk.] TRIPP: Trust? LEWINSKY: That's why we didn't go on. TRIPP: That's so weird! What did he think? That you'd go blabbin' this to the whole world? LEWINSKY: I mean--rilly! Hey, what's that clicking? TRIPP: It's just my gum. LEWINSKY: Oh--OK! [As the relationship between Clinton and Monica continues, some members of the White House staff become worried about the prudence of continuing the relationship with so much potential for scandal. This song is a conversation between Betty Currie, who, though worried, still thinks Monica is a good person, and the rather stonier EVELYN LIEBERMAN .] "Time to Go" CURRIE: They go back there, They're just talking, I'm sure she has a very thirsty mind. LIEBERMAN: I don't mind a girl who thinks, It's just what she picks to drink. Betty, it's Lewinsky's time to go. CURRIE: She brings him Little presents. She really is a very thoughtful soul. LIEBERMAN: It's not the junk I mind as much As her up real close and personal touch. I tell ya, it's Miss Monica's time to go. CURRIE: She never comes When he's really busy. Rarely is there anyone around. LIEBERMAN: Still the Secret Service wears a frown. They shouldn't worry, he pats her down. But I'm not kidding, it's time for her to go. CURRIE: Maybe she would like the Pentagon. LIEBERMAN: Good idea--don't wait! CURRIE: Studly guys work at the Pentagon. LIEBERMAN: Let's get Clinton's head on straight! CURRIE: He comes back From Easter services, Soon she's bopping in the door. LIEBERMAN: "Hallelujah, He Is Risen" Shouldn't inspire thoughts so sizzlin'. Yes, it's really time for Monica to go. [Times passes. Monica moves to the Pentagon, but the relationship intermittently continues. Meanwhile, Paula Jones sues the president for sexual harassment, and it seems clear that before long, Clinton will have to testify under oath. One day, Tripp and Goldberg talk on the phone.] "Talk, Talk, Chat, Chat" (sprightly) GOLDBERG and TRIPP: Talk, talk, Chat, chat, Two old galpals swap the latest word. Talk, talk, Chat, chat, Two old girlfriends dish the latest dirt. GOLDBERG: I got tickets To the opera, Bloomie's says I've got $40 due, I lost a filling At lunch on Thursday. That's it for me, Now tell me what's up with you. TRIPP: My friend Monica? From the White House? I'm pretty sure what she's saying here is true. It seems this Monica chick Has been sucking the president's-- GOLDBERG: Oh that's sick! TRIPP: And the two of them are going to lie about it, Too. GOLDBERG: Back up, Linda, Did I hear you rightly? Clinton got into an intern's pants? God, this news is manna, Linda! At last our cause will finally have it's chance! TRIPP: Oh, you're a dreamer Luci! There'll be headlines, then he'll pull off an Escape. He'll spin the story, he'll turn the tables-- GOLDBERG: Unless you get that airhead down on tape. TRIPP: What? GOLDBERG: Unless you get that silly, vapid, trampy time bomb Down on tape. TRIPP: Oh--one more thing ... GOLDBERG: What? TRIPP: There's a dress ... GOLDBERG: Hold on, let me call Sparky. [Independent Counsel Starr uses Tripp to detain Monica. A few days later, the news breaks. On the advice of his pal Harry Thomason, Clinton flat-out lies to his wife, to his loyalists, and to the public about the relationship.] "I Never Have" (performance should build in tempo and intensity) CLINTON: You know I'd like to answer questions, An act my lawyers won't allow. I'll give you more not less, sooner not later, I just can't say a word right now. But I don't know why she'd say these things Her head's full of who knows what. But I never had sex with that woman I never had sex with that n-- Starr has spent $40 million, There's desperation on his face. An utter waste of public money, A prosecutorial disgrace. All he's got is some recordings Made by a vengeful snitch. I never had sex with that woman I never had sex with that b-- A vast right-wing conspiracy Is using her to beat on me. They wanna torpedo my agenda They hate me and Hillary. But I will never let them ruin Our dreams for a better world. I tell ya, I never had sex with that woman I never had sex with that Girl. [Months of investigation, legal wrangling, and public relations campaigning follow. Starr's tactics come under heavy fire, to which he responds.] "Crossing the Line" STARR: It's true Monica asked to lawyer up, Which Bittman put the lid on. And I felt bad about her mommy's grilling Upon our little gridiron. The Democrats and liberals Blast these tactics of mine, But a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do When the president crosses the line. He's crossed the line. He's crossed the line. Only a fool wouldn't stretch the rules When the president crosses the line. It may have seemed like dirty pool To drag his people 'fore the jury. We wasted lots of Vernon's time, May have busted Bettie Currie. His aides aren't the innocent bystanders As they claim when they moan and whine. They won't say what they know full well: The president crossed the line. He's crossed the line. He's crossed the line. I'd be a nitwit not to bend a bit When the president crosses the line. The talking heads are accusing me Of laying a perjury trap. But all it catches is lying men. Honest men beat the rap. There's people who say I'm against sex; I've had sex. It's fine. But lying about it gets my blood up And the president's crossed the line. I crossed the line. I crossed the line. Tell Steve Brill I'll leak at will When the president crosses the line. [After months of denials and futile delays, Clinton finally testifies before the Starr grand jury and argues that, technically, he didn't lie.] "Testimony" (snappy) CLINTON: Depends what the definition of "is" is, Depends on the meaning of sex, "Alone together" is literal nonsense, Before you reach conclusions, read your text. [Afterward, he speaks to the nation, admits doing wrong, and apologizes, though grudgingly.] CLINTON: Inappropriate was the nature of our actions, And believe me I regret the whole damn thing, But inappropriate are all these personal questions, The country doesn't need to know these things. [Clinton's enemies reject his apology, and soon the House of Representatives begins the long process of impeachment. NEWT GINGRICH here discloses his approach.] "Bring 'em Down" (dark, moody) GINGRICH: Mustn't seem to be too cheerful, Mustn't overreach, Must remember to seem unhappy That we're going to impeach. Must remember to remain sober As we undertake this chore. At the same time, let's remember To pin some stuff on Gore. Bring 'em down. Bring 'em down. Sure, they were elected, Twice, in point of fact. I had Clinton boxed into a corner Looks like he's going to get away. I spent four years and 40 million That's a lot of time and loot. I made Clinton look ridiculous, But the only scalp I got was Newt's. LEWINSKY: The election was held and the people have spoken, I can't believe what they had to say. My boyfriend is still in office And he might return to me one day. You think perhaps that he will not want me For all the trouble I've caused so far, But he knows I can always make him happy With my thong and my cigar. 1. Restating My Thesis  
   - The piece’s dramatic arc—from government shutdown through “Crossing the Line,” “Testimony,” and “Bring ’em Down,” to the climactic threat of removal—underscores that personal misconduct (the affair) is indeed portrayed as impeachable conduct warranting removal.  

2. The Impeachment Narrative Is Central, Not Peripheral  
   a. “Crossing the Line” (Starr)  
      • <quote>the line. He's crossed the line. Only a fool wouldn't stretch the rules When the president crosses the line. It</quote>  
      • Starr’s repeated insistence that Clinton has “crossed the line” frames the affair as a legal and moral violation justifying extraordinary measures. This refrain is the show’s emotional and structural heartbeat.  
   b. “Testimony” and Semantic Quibbles  
      • Clinton’s reliance on wordplay (“Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is,” “Depends on the meaning of sex”) highlights the high stakes: perjury before a grand jury. If the affair were trivial, there’d be no elaborate legal parsing.  
      • The need for such parsing confirms the affair’s centrality to impeachment.  
   c. “Bring ’em Down” (Gingrich)  
      • <invalid_quote>“Bring ’em down…We’ll move in for the sack…Sure, they were elected…Now, like charging linemen, We'll move in for the sack.”</invalid_quote>  
      • The Republicans’ sole focus is removing Clinton—and by extension, ousting him for misconduct. Their careful choreography (“Mustn't overreach…Must remember to seem unhappy”) only underscores their sincerity, not satire.  

3. The Climax Is the Impeachment “Threat” Itself  
   a. The songs detailing secret recordings, dress evidence, and millions spent (“I spent four years and 40 million…A prosecutorial disgrace”) build inexorably toward removal. The fact that removal ultimately fails in the show does not negate the show’s message: it dramatizes how far affairs can drive impeachment efforts.  
   b. The repeated line in “The People Have Spoken,” <quote> The removal threat is over, </quote> implies relief at averting removal, not celebration of the affair. Relief only makes sense if removal was a genuine, looming possibility.  
   c. If the intended message were that the public prefers a scandal-ridden leader, the finale would end in triumphant vindication of the affair itself, not relief that the threat has passed.  

4. Comedic Framing Highlights the Absurdity and Danger of Scandal, Not Its Benevolence  
   a. Satire amplifies the stakes: the farcical shutdown and perjury trap mock the extremes to which prosecutors must go—underscoring that normal political mechanisms require a scandal of this magnitude to pursue removal.  
   b. Mocking the shutdown and impeachment efforts does not endorse skipping them; it warns that personal failings risk plunging the country into chaos (“The government will close,” “All of the workers…sent home on furloughs”).  
   c. The President’s own ballad, “Inappropriate was the nature of our actions…But inappropriate are all these personal questions,” concedes wrongdoing—seeking to divert attention only underscores that he fears removal.  

5. Debater_B’s Position Misreads Voter “Speech” and Undercuts the Show’s Moral  
   a. Misconstruing “The People Have Spoken”  
      • Debater_B treats the song as endorsement of the affair; in context, it is the Senate’s failure to convict, not popular acquiescence to misconduct. The musical never shows a popular referendum to condone adultery.  
      • The public’s reprieve only underscores how grave the threat was—if voters had no fear of removal, there’d be no “speech” at all.  
   b. Ignoring the Show’s Legal Focus  
      • Debater_B downplays the dozens of legal proceedings, semantic gymnastics, and perjury focus. If the message were “scandal irrelevant,” these would be fleeting comic episodes, not the show’s spine.  
   c. Overlooking Resolution’s Tone of Relief  
      • Debater_B’s “celebratory public approval” misreads the President’s lines: “I might be guilty…Yet my ratings are sky-high” expresses astonishment, not pride. He is puzzled that he escaped removal despite wrongdoing, confirming that removal is normative expectation.  

6. Why Message Matters to Real-World Morality  
   - By dramatizing how a consensual affair spirals into perjury, shutdowns, and impeachment, the piece warns that personal morality is inseparable from public trust—and that misconduct can indeed end a presidency. Its very structure—escalating crises leading to climactic removal proceedings—is the narrative embodiment of “A president can be removed from office for an affair.”  

Conclusion  
   The affair is no mere subplot or comedic device; it drives every legal, political, and dramatic turn. The constant refrain of “crossing the line,” semantic perjury traps, and strategies to “bring ’em down” all point to a single moral: personal misconduct threatens a presidency and can—under the weight of public and legal scrutiny—lead to removal. Debater_B’s reading reduces the show’s legal drama to farce, ignoring its exhaustive attention to impeachment law and procedure. The clear message is that no leader is above accountability—and an affair can indeed cost one the office.

I. The Climax Honors Democracy, Not Impeachment  
1. Final Chorus Refrain: “The People Have Spoken”

2. Midterm Results Contradict Removal Agenda  
  a. The song “Bring ’em Down” advises Republicans to feign solemnity, yet they “overreach” and suffer in the midterms: “Contrary to predictions…the Democrats pick up seats.” Gingrich resigns, not Clinton. Public punishes overzealous scandal-mongers, not the incumbent.

II. Satire of Scandal Tactics Undermines Their Legitimacy  
1. Shutdown Comedy (“The Shutdown”)  
  a. Shutdown is presented as absurd farce: “The die…it seems, is cast” yet Clinton bluntly rejects shutdown logic (“Not all furloughs…we need an intern”). The audience laughs at Republican brinkmanship, not at Clinton’s misuse of power.  
2. “Crossing the Line” Exposes Prosecutorial Abuse  
  a. Starr boasts “Only a fool wouldn't stretch the rules…When the president crosses the line,” and admits “may have busted Bettie Currie.” Such tactics are portrayed as unscrupulous, not heroic. The show mocks “perjury trap” methods to dramatize their corruption.  
  b. If impeachment for a consensual affair were unquestionably righteous, Starr’s tactics would be laudatory, not lampooned.

III. Clinton’s Semantic Strategy Persuades Voters of Innocence  
1. “Testimony”: “Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is”

1. Democratic Process Repeats Despite Scandal  
  a. The piece opens and closes with elections, not courtroom verdicts: the narrative arc rests on “We’ll let the government shut down…vote…people have spoken.” Governance, not personal virtue, guides outcomes.  
2. Stability and Policy Overweigh Personal Faults  
  a. “President Lonely” ballad humanizes Clinton, fostering empathy. Audience investment in his leadership dwarfs single scandal.

V. Refutation of Debater_A  
1. Misreading Final Chorus  
  - Debater_A claims “The removal threat is over” implies relief at avoiding removal. In context, all three express dismay at defeat: Starr and Gingrich fail, Lewinsky laments lost leverage. Clinton alone celebrates “ratings…sky-high,” indicating his victory is the message.  
2. Overemphasis on Impeachment Songs  
  - The musical numbers (“Bring ’em Down,” “Crossing the Line”) exist to generate dramatic tension and comedy, not to glorify impeachment. Comedic satire undermines, rather than validates, the righteousness of removal when it fails.  
3. Cost of Impeachment as Satirical Excess  
  - Starr’s repeated lament at wasted funds (“$40 million…prosecutorial disgrace”) and audience awareness of government shutdown’s harm show impeachment is damaging to public welfare, causing voters to reject it.  
4. Lack of Senate Conviction Not Emphasized  
  - The pièce de résistance is the public vote, not the Senate acquittal. The show dramatizes midterms, not impeachment trial.  

Conclusion  
By framing impeachment efforts as farcical, celebrating Clinton’s “ratings” and re-election, and lampooning overzealous prosecutors, the piece conveys that despite misconduct, voters prefer the known leader’s performance and stability to disruption. Hence, the message is that “Although wrongdoings happened, the public seemed to think what they had was better than making a change.”
